data.text: #Tonga: IMF Executive Board approves US$9.95 million in emergency financing to help the country meet its urgent economic and healthcare needs to cope with the #pandemic https://t.co/We7mLVZLEL https://t.co/e0CQipLWun

The strength of recovery varies across countries. Growth will hinge on the severity of the health crisis, the extent of lockdowns & disruptions to activity, cross-border spillovers, and the effectiveness of policy support to limit persistent damage. #WEO https://t.co/yIs7h1GvE2 https://t.co/4F4wVGjEmH

As the world emerges from the #COVID19 crisis, the global economy is at a critical juncture. The recovery will be shaped by whichever is faster: the virus or the vaccines. Watch the #WEO video. https://t.co/yIs7h1GvE2 https://t.co/S2dqpGajwB

We project global growth of 5.5% for 2021 but much depends on the outcome of the race between the virus and vaccines and on the policy support provided. Read @GitaGopinath’s latest #IMFblog. #WEO https://t.co/l6a6MLEYha https://t.co/QPnvnBQkjh

The global economy is projected to grow 5.5% in 2021, a slight upward revision from the previous forecast, reflecting expectations of a vaccine-powered strengthening of activity later in the year and additional policy support in a few large economies. #WEO https://t.co/yIs7h1GvE2 https://t.co/VnY87DPEAR
